item.title: AKS Advanced Load Balancing Part 2: Kubernetes Services
item.description: Overview In my last post I focused on getting a deeper understanding of how AKS interacts with Azure, and specifically the Azure Load Balancer (ALB), to route traffic into a cluster. We walked through the default hashed based load balancing algorithm, and then showed the routing and ALB impact of using the Kubernetes service sessionAffinity mode of ‘ClientIP’ to enable sticky sessions. If you haven’t run through that, then I’d definitely give part 1 a read before continuing here.
